Karl,

Yes, the flow controllers have changed in 1.5.4, and are now simpler.   
The use of a PID controller seemed to be overkill, and has now been  
removed (but can be restored if desired).  If you are writing your code  
in C++, take a look at Cantera/src/zeroD/flowControllers.h. It defines  
the existing flow controllers, which are MassFlowController, Valve, and  
a new one PressureController.  A PressureController is designed to go  
on an outlet of a reactor, and is slaved to another flow controller on  
an inlet.  Its mass flow rate is equal to the inlet flow controller's  
mass flow rate, plus a term linear in the pressure difference.  This  
allows easily maintaining a constant pressure in a reactor with  
time-varying input mass flow rate.

Use it as shown here:

FlowDevice *mfc, *pc;
mfc = new MassFlowController();
pc = new PressureController();
pc->setMaster(mfc):

Set the coefficient of the linear term the same way you would for a  
valve (method setParameters). If your code is Python or Matlab, the  
syntax is simpler.  This will all be covered in the document I am  
finishing up now that should be done in a few days.

Dave




On Jun 18, 2004, at 1:58 PM, kvirgilm wrote:

> I have a code I've been using with 1.5.3.  I want to move to 1.5.4.   
> I've
> installed 1.5.4 and the examples work fine.  When I compile my code, I  
> get
> the following linking errors.  It seems like it is having problems  
> with the
> pressure regulator and other flow controller devices.  Has this changed
> significantly since 1.5.3?  If so, what do I use instead of  
> PressureRegulator?
>

> g++ -o ./cstr cstr.o
